title: Error in stdout, position of error not correctly printed

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
## Steps to reproduce

```
git clone https://github.com/fschutt/webrender
cd webrender
git checkout cac72f1 # alternatively "checkout remove-sha2"
cargo check
```

## Output

```
   Compiling webrender v0.60.0
error: invalid format string: expected `'}'`, found `'p'`
  --> webrender/build.rs:83:20
   |
83 | /// If someone is building on a network share, I'm sorry.
   |              -     ^ expected `}` in format string
   |              |
   |              because of this opening brace
   |
   = note: if you intended to print `{`, you can escape it using `{{`

error: aborting due to previous error

error: Could not compile `webrender`.

To learn more, run the command again with --verbose.
```

Source code for that line is [here](https://github.com/fschutt/webrender/blob/cac72f12f3091658ddd22e9c987c3aeb4d114d10/webrender/build.rs#L83). For some reason, the line count is off by a few lines, the actual error happens within the expansion of the `include_str!` macro on line 75:

```rust
write!(shader_file, include_str!("./combined_shaders.rs"), shader_source_code);
```

My goal was to use a "template" file in the "./combined_shaders.rs" file - however, I used `{}` instead of `{{}}` to show where the dynamic content should be inserted [here](https://github.com/fschutt/webrender/blob/cac72f12f3091658ddd22e9c987c3aeb4d114d10/webrender/combined_shaders.rs#L17). Nevermind, this is still a bug (since the line count should at least be on line 75 and underline the `include_str!`).

## Compiler version
```
rustc 1.35.0 (3c235d560 2019-05-20)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: 3c235d5600393dfe6c36eeed34042efad8d4f26e
commit-date: 2019-05-20
host: x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu
release: 1.35.0
LLVM version: 8.0
```
